Dipping into foreign reserves and making small tweaks to spending can get you only so far. Oil at $40 a barrel is hurting the six states of the Gulf Co-operation Council, for which the black stuff accounts for over 80% of government revenues. They not only spend lavishly, but their private sectors depend on public projects and the oil industry. Saudi Arabia, Oman and Bahrain are particularly vulnerable. Their rulers are removing subsidies on fuel, electricity and water. All six states—including better-off Kuwait, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates—will introduce VAT by 2018; they are looking at other taxes, too. Balancing the books requires much more, though, such as easing conditions for new businesses and cutting huge public payrolls. That won’t be easy. The Gulf populations are growing rapidly. People have got used to handouts. But if the rulers don’t break their oil addiction now, bigger problems lie ahead
[From the Economist Espresso]
====NOTE=====
I'm citing a paper The Natural Resource Curse: A Survey http://www.nber.org/papers/w15836
"The resource curse, also known as the paradox of plenty, refers to the paradox that countries with an abundance of natural resources, specifically non-renewable resources like minerals and fuels, tend to have less economic growth, less democracy, and worse development outcomes than countries with fewer natural resources. This is hypothesized to happen for many different reasons, and there are many academic debates about when and why it occurs. Most experts believe the resource curse is not universal or inevitable, but affects certain types of countries or regions under certain conditions."

The market needs to move by -50% from today's current price in a span of 40 days.  Price decreases (aggregated over any amount of time until the market turns in the other direction) of -30% have only occurred at a frequency of 7% over the past +28 years.  I have set my baseline at 7% despite the downtown required is -50%, which has occurred 2% of the time during the same timespan, because three market downturns (-79%, -30% and -40%) have occurred in the span of 1.6 years.  I observe that 2014-2015-2016 the market has averaged one month losses whereas previously the market's worst year averaged a 0.6 month loss before turning.  My 7% probability the market will drop by -50% in the next 40 days accounts for the 2x longer periods of loss observed in the past 18 months than ever before.

A hint of bullishness has returned. The International Energy Agency said on Friday that crude prices “may have bottomed out”. Brent, the world standard, has breached $40 per barrel and West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark, is close to it. Today OPEC’s report for February may help too, if it shows that Saudi Arabia and Russia honoured their agreement to freeze output at January’s (record) levels, and Iran’s post-sanctions exports are less aggressive than expected. But the bulls’ case is unconvincing. Other producers are in disarray over when and where to meet to discuss further output curbs. Iran’s first shipment to Europe arrived last week and its officials say exports will rise sharply by May. Global demand remains anaemic and stocks are at record highs. Moreover, the urgency to cut production is less than it was at $30. Expect more turbulence
[From the Economist Espresso]

I forecast this event to be highly unlikely, giving it a 10% chance for happening. To come to this, I applied M (mathematical and statistical models help) and O (other perspectives should also inform your forecasts) from CHAMPS KNOW. For math, the current price of a barrel is $31.40, which means that a greater than 35% drop would have to happen by the date just two months away. Looking at other historical drops, the only time a percentage drop that great has been seen recently was at the onset of the recession. There is little reason to believe we are on the brink of a major global recession, and even if we were, it would have to arrive in the next few weeks for a drop to be realized before May 1. Also, it has been over 15 years since the price has fallen below $20. I also looked at other perspectives to refine my judgment, notably the perspective of countries with a large stake in oil prices. Specifically, Saudi Arabia, Russia, and Venezuela have had consistent talks in recent months of an output freeze. An output freezes, as they indicate will likely occur, will help stabilize short-term prices and hinder and further drops. Because of these two major factors, in addition to the quickly approaching time deadline for this question, it seems rare that a drop this large will occur.

It must first be recognized that nobody knows when or at what level the oil price will find a minimum.  But if we start with the outside view, prices have for the past 43 years moved in cycles (starting with the embargo during the 1973 Arab Israeli conflict).  Before that time it was the Texas Railroad Commission that regulated the price.  Since then the price has moved in long cycles, depending on investment levels and on supply and demand cycles.  The last time crude exceeded $100/brl (2008) it subsequently dropped sharply.  Recently (~2011 to 2014) the price exceeded $100 for a sustained period of time.  The high price financed the shale boom in North America.  The higher the price, and the longer the duration of the high price, the more severe the correction that we should expect.

Looking at the supply side impact of geopolitical events, my initial take is that there likely impact is too mixed to make a meaningful directional call. I'm frankly not convinced whether the continued uncertainty over the wars in Yemen and Syria may lead Saudi to double down or reverse its economic war against Iran through maintaining low oil prices. Therefore, for my initial forecast, I thought I'd start on the demand side. As a starting point I plotted daily Brent prices from FRED going back to 1989 and compared them to the dates of US recessions. While the data set is very limited, the average decline from peak to trough in Brent prices in the run-up and through a US recession is 60%. Using the Dec 2013 price level as the peak, Brent's recent sub-USD30 low reflects a 77% decline (slightly worse than the fall from July-December 2008). For prices to fall below USD20, this would imply ~83% decline from the Dec 2013 peak, which looking at strictly in terms of energy prices, would imply a slightly worse financial crisis than the GFC. Uncertainty over China's shift to lower-rate growth amid the rebalancing of its economy from investment to consumption-driven growth, makes that kind of scenario slightly more likely. I do think that if we get down to USD20 a barrel, a sharp rebound would be likely either by sparking a reversal in Saudi-led policy or a geopolitical risk spike triggered by a crisis of confidence in the ability of Saudi to maintain economic stability amid sustained pressure on its reserves. I'm putting the probability at 20% as my initial forecast. A weekly close above USD40 would lead me to drop this down sharply to 10%. If next week's close continues to stay above 35, I'd likely reduce more gradually towards 15%. A weekly close below USD30 would lead me to raise gradually toward 25%, and a close below USD25 would lead me to raise sharply to 40%+.

Following the path started in 2015, U.S. commercial crude oil inventories have continued to build in early 2016 and are nearing record highs. Stocks in the Gulf Coast reached 256 million barrels for the week ending February 19, while stocks at Cushing, Oklahoma, reached their highest recorded level of 65 million barrels for the week ending February 19 (Figure 1). U.S. commercial crude oil inventory builds at this time of year are not unusual, as planned maintenance at U.S. refiners typically reduces runs in January and February. However, with inventories already high after generally building over the past 18 months, this turnaround season could push storage capacity use to new highs. The result may be lower crude oil prices and higher price volatility in the near future.

For a base rate I downloaded the EIA monthly and weekly data and then computed percent changes for periods of two months, three months, and 11 weeks (current time to 1 May).  To meet criteria for a yes would require a drop of about 31%.  So I counted the number of times there has been at least a 31% drop in each of those time periods (in other words, each time the trailing 3 month change > 31%).  I came up with ~2% of the available time periods since 1987 (based on dataset from EIA).   All of those time periods came from the current drop starting in 2015 and the 2008 drop.  A curious fact is that there seem to be more large increases than decreases.  Not sure of the reason, although it could be that in previous times of uncertainty, people bought up commodities that they thought could be scarce and hence a decent store of value.
